results.title: Introduction to design
results.creator_credit: F Treuthardt, John Kingsford-Smith and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Advance Australia”.
Made to foster an appreciation of the basic simple shapes in design. Poses the question “What is design?”. Answers that design is simply an orderly arrangement of lines and shapes. Aboriginal art in its simplicity of design is drawn from nature - if you look up, down and around you will too. Simple motifs are used in everyday articles.

results.title: Hydro-electric power
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Advance Australia”.
Describes the way in which moisture laden cloud becomes rain, and eventually a flowing river with perhaps a waterfall included in its course. The principles of hydro-electric power are explained and model maps are used to show a plan of the Snowy Mountains undertaking.

results.title: Adolescent Development
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Social sex attitudes in adolescence
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Adolescent Development”.
A document on the lives of fictitious Bob and Mary, focusing on the teen years. Here, lovestruck Mary is in her “hangout” stage when she always has a need to be “more sophisticated than she actually is.” Cross to Bob where his mother discovers a crude naughty drawing in his room and narrator Lorne Greene croons: “It became apparent that his interest in girls was getting to be more than casual.” But happily, Mary has maintained her virginal purity: “They knew that this time it was for keeps.” says Greene as the two gaze at a window display of refrigerators. But the couple refuse to succumb to temptation until they’re married.

results.title: Social acceptability
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Adolescent Development”.
Depicts a high school girl who is not accepted by a popular school clique, illustrating the correlation between social acceptability and the successful adjustment and happiness of the average adolescent. It further brings out the responsibility of parents to provide adolescents with guidance in the social skills and opportunities to put these into practice. Correlated with the book ‘Adolescent Development’ by Elizabeth B. Hurlock.

results.title: Physical aspects of puberty
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Adolescent Development”.
Describes, chiefly through animation, the physiological aspects of puberty in girls and boys. Shows that the behaviour problems which seem emotional are often based on the rate of physical growth

results.title: Meeting the needs of adolescents
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Adolescent Development”.
This film describes some of the ways in which parents may help prepare their children for adulthood. It deals with a family which includes a seventeen-year-old girl and a fourteen-year-old boy. It shows how their basic physical needs are met, how they are guided in their spiritual growth, and how parents can develop the social consciousness which will service to aid their children in making a satisfactory adjustment in later life. The film points out what parents can do to help constructively and indicates some of the needless worries that parents have about their teenagers.

results.title: The Meaning of adolescence
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Adolescent Development”.
Describes the status of the adolescent , in relation to the social, emotional, mental and physical changes occurring in the years between childhood and adulthood. Points out that adults, through proper understanding, can help the teenager adjust to aspects of adult life.

results.title: Emotional maturity
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Adolescent Development”.
A docu-drama depicting the immature behaviour of an adolescent boy who fails to channel his emotions into positive feelings and actions. After being rejected by his girlfriend, Dave seeks revenge by slashing her new boyfriend’s tyres. Deeper investigation suggests that Dave’s parents have contributed to his ‘emotional instability’ by treating him like a child.
